results.title: The Airport
results.brief_description: Bridget Robertson goes to the airport to collect her sister’s body. She reflects on Tina’s life, cut short at 25 in a motor bike accident.

results.title: Darling child
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: Kalin’s short video works function both as visual poems and as alternative music videos. With their astute conjunctions of image, music and text, these tapes respond to issues of sexuality and human interaction in the 1990s. In Darling Child, Kalin uses an economy of means spare visuals of an interior space, minimalist music to create an evocative, metaphoric interpretation of a text by Truman Capote. “But we are alone, darling child, terribly, isolated from the other; so fierce is the world’s ridicule we cannot speak or show our tenderness; for us death is stronger than life, it pulls like a wind through the dark, all our cries burlesqued in joyless laughter; and with the garbage of loneliness stuffed down us until our guts burst bleeding green, we go screaming round the world, dying in our rented rooms, nightmare hotels, eternal homes of the transient heart.” — Truman Capote, Other Voices, Other Rooms.

results.title: Big hearted kid
results.brief_description:
Cameron through the use of his “talker” tells of his background, his intense shyness as a child and lack of confidence until the age of 23 when Karen, Rhonda and Mel came into his life. He has become a role model for kids aged 6 to 14 who use talkers and an inspiration to all those who work with him in the disability area.
This project was funded by the Department of Human Services, (Eastern Metropolitan Region), developed and executed in partnership with MetroAccess at the City of Monash and City of Whitehorse, and Scope.

results.title: Rev
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: This painterly observation of pedestrian traffic through a revolving door finds a counterpoint in the flickering of a candle flame. As separate lives are blurred with the energy of constant movement, individuals merge into an abstracted urban sound and light space.

results.title: Finally destroy us
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: Kalin’s short video works function both as visual poems and as alternative music videos. With their astute conjunctions of image, music and text, these tapes respond to issues of sexuality and human interaction in the 1990s, more than a decade into the AIDS crisis. In finally destroy us, Kalin uses found film footage, home movies, and haunting pop music (Annie Lenox singing Cole Porter) to poignantly recall moments of love, shared and lost. The title is taken from Virginia Woolf: ‘But these meetings, these partings, finally destroy us’.
results.description: Kalin’s short video works function both as visual poems and as alternative music videos. results.title: Inside outside...inside out
results.brief_description: Kristie remembers her childhood and teenage years as unhappy ones, of abuse and internal struggle. But at age 19, her life began to turn around through three very special people - Linda, Liz and Penny.

results.title: 3 years = Three years
results.brief_description: For Calvin, joining up with Green Corps when he was 20 proved to be a turning point in his life. Motivated and inspired by the people he met in Green Corps, three years on, he is now successfully employed, confident and making the most of every opportunity that comes his way.
